tabs.header_iregular:
Let's keep this eczema under control.

The goal in managing eczema that is available over the counter is to:

  • moisturize the skin
     
  • prevent the skin from losing water
     
  • improve the integrity of the skin
     
  • prevent any infection from the scratching. 

Some of the ways to achieve these are listed below.

collapsable.title: Moisturizers click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This will be used to hydrate the skin. The more moisture the skin can retain, the better. Not only does moisturizers increase the water content of the skin, they also act as a barrier against moisture loss.

Make sure you choose one that is free of perfumes, additives or fragrances. Apply as often as you feel you need it. Your goal is to keep the skin moist all the time.

Cream, ointment or lotion. Which should you choose?    

Well, the ointment lasts longer on the skin but is more greasy.
The cream vanishes into the skin, less greasy, but not as long lasting as the ointment.
Lotion spread easily, but last in terms of duration.

Our best advice is to use what you prefer. Keep cream with you everywhere you go, ointment for legs, cream or lotion for the hands since you can easily reapply on the hand anywhere you are.

collapsable.title: Bathing practices click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
A warm bath at least once a day for 10 minutes. Use a neutral or low pH non-soap cleanser. Make sure it is fragrance-free and hypoallergenic.

Moisturize immediately after bathing.

collapsable.title: Cortizone click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Hydrocortisone 1% is the strongest over-the-counter steroid you can use for inflammation and itch.

Use this once a while to prevent flare-ups.

Make sure you don't rub this to a large skin area.

collapsable.title: Wet-wrap therapy click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will use wet-wrap therapy to quickly reduce flares in areas of red, hot, weeping eczema. 

To use a wet wrap, first moisturize your skin after bathing, get wet bandages, wrap around the skin.
Then wrap a layer of dry bandages over the wet bandages and secure it.

What this does is to increase penetration of the moisturizer, makes sure you don't scratch the area, reduce the loss of water from your skin and makes the skin heal quicker.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/07/2016

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over the counter to help with this burn.

Know that the burns you can take care of yourself are first degree burns and second degree burns not larger than 3 inches in diameter.

Anything outside this, you must seek urgent medical care.

Hope you ran cool water over the burn area to help reduce the swelling.

Most burns heal without any problems but you want to avoid scaring or discoloration of the affected skin area and this  often depend on how you took care of it, especially within the first few days after the burn.

Measures available over the counter to help with minor burns include :

  • taking care of the pain
     
  • preventing any infection and
     
  • dressing the area if need be.

With this in mind, see what is recommended to help with this burn  below.

collapsable.title: Initially click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
---  Remove any rings, bracelets, watches from the affected area in case any swelling occur.

---  Clean the area with soap and water  to remove debris.

---  Do not burst the blisters if any and do not apply antiseptics like povidone/iodine or betadine.

---  Need to keep the area moist. So apply cocoa butter, vaseline to the area.

---  If no blistering, better to leave it open.
 

---  If some blisters, you will have to get a dressing like DuoDerm®, TegaDerm®; or Xerofoam®.

collapsable.title: Relieving pain click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
NSAIDs

Take ibuprofen or naproxen to help with the pain and minimize possible swelling that will take place.

Lidocaine

Ask for 4% lidocaine at the pharmacy counter and apply to the affected area. This should provide pain relief that will last long. If the pharmacy is closed, over-the-counter Lanacaine should help for now.

Aloe vera

Apply this to soothe the area if you can't find lidocaine or your skin is sensitive to lidocaine. Look for pure aloe vera leaf if you can find one. Know that 100% pure Aloe vera doesn't mean it is only aloe vera in the bottle. This means they used aloe vera plant and not processed aloe vera. Other things are added to the mixture.

collapsable.title: Preventing infection click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Bacitracin or triple antibiotic ointment would help. Apply this to the affected area

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Use sunscreen on the affected area to prevent discoloration for a few months.
     
  • If this is a burned foot, use it to walk. If not, the foot will swell.
    No clutches or walker. Better to hurt now than later when it gets swollen.
     
  • Medical grade honey such as medihoney®.
    To be considered potent to heal burns, look for a minimum rating of 10 UMF (unique manuka factor).

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/07/2016

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's act fast to slow down this damaging effect on your skin.

The goal of managing sunburn would be to:

  1. Relieve pain and inflammation.
  2. Prevent dehydration by keeping hydrated.
  3. Moisturize the skin.
  4. Protect the skin from more damage.
  5. Reduce the risk of infection.
  6. Stay away from the sun for a while.

With this in mind, let's use this to take care of this sunburn..

collapsable.title: Initially click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Move and stay away from direct sunlight, preferably go indoors or under a shade.
  • Cool the skin by:
    - sponging it with cool water or  
    - a cool shower for about 10 minutes or
    - a cool compress with a wet towel
  • Drink plenty of water.

collapsable.title: Moisturize click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Aloe vera

This will provide a soothing effect, increase skin healing and protect the skin against moisture loss.

What to look out for in choosing a good aloe vera gel:

  • Watch out for a sales ploy of 100% gel. This is not the same as 100% aloe vera gel.    
  • Also 100% natural, is not the same as 100% natural aloe vera gel. These usually contain other natural ingredients.
  • A gel with vitamin E is preferred to reduce any stinging effect.
  • Usually the more expensive the gel, the better.
  • If you want a 100% aloe vera gel, you will need to get the plant from the supermarket.    

After sun soothers:    

These usually contain aloe vera mixed with other soothing ingredients.

They will soothe the skin, moisturize it and reduce the feeling of the skin feeling tight.

Good products are Burt's Bees and Hawaiian Tropics after sun products.

collapsable.title: If itchy click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Calamine lotion    

2. Sarna lotion for cooling effect

3. Hydrocortisone to very inflamed areas only.

collapsable.title: Pain and inflammation click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
NSAIDs

Ibuprofen or naproxen will help with pain and inflammation. Take as soon as possible.

Acetaminophen

Take this if you cannot take ibuprofen or naproxen.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/07/2016

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out how to take care of this poison ivy rash.

The goal with over the counter treatment of poison ivy is to:

  1. Remove the oil as much as you can to curtail spreading.
     
  2. Relieve the itching.
     
  3. Dry the rash using an astringent.
     
  4. Reduce the skin inflammation.
     
  5. Protect the skin from further damage.

 Take a look at over the counter medications that will accomplish this below, and you will then answer a few questions to see how to apply these to your case of poison ivy rash.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose your symptoms from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: At the tingling or prodrome stage
Small blisters grew together to form a large blister.
Sore is red, raised a little.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

If you think you have a flu:

Please go back and choose the symptom(s) that you feel closely relate to what you have or might have had and let's recommend something for you.

Remember, there is no cure for the flu. All we can do is manage the symptoms if you have one.
mode.2: Something to prevent or boost your resistance to the flu?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have the flu really bad.

Discuss further?
mode.4: You will need an antihistamine.
mode.5: Selection require a decongestant.
mode.6: Selection require a pain / fever reducer.
mode.7: Need an expectorant with or a cough suppressant.
mode.8: Need to quiet down the stomach.
mode.9: Need a decongestant and pain / fever medication based on your selection.
mode.10: Symptoms require an antihistamine and a pain / fever reliever.
mode.11: Selection require an expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever reducer.
mode.12: Selection require stomach and pain / fever relief aids.
mode.13: Need an antihistamine and a decongestant.
mode.14: Selection require antihistamine and an expectorant with or cough suppressant.
mode.15: Symptoms require an antihistamine and stomach relief medications.
mode.16: Need a decongestant and an expectorant with or cough suppressant.
mode.17: A decongestant and stomach relief medications are required.
mode.18: Will need an expectorant with or cough suppressant and a stomach relief medication.
mode.19: Symptoms require an antihistamine, decongestant and a pain / fever reducer.
mode.20: Need an antihistamine, expectorant with or cough suppressant and a pain / fever reducer.
mode.21: Selection require an antihistamine, stomach relief and pain / fever reducer.
mode.22: Need a pain / fever reducer, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant relief.
mode.23: Selection require a decongestant, stomach and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.24: Need a pain / fever, stomach and expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.25: Symptoms require a decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and stomach relief medications.
mode.26: Will need an antihistamine, expectorant with or cough suppressant and stomach relief medications.
mode.27: Will need an antihistamine, decongestant and an expectorant / cough suppressant medicatons.
mode.28: Selection require an antihistamine, decongestant and stomach relief medications.
mode.29: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, pain / fever and stomach relief medications.
mode.30: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.31: Need an antihistamine, stomach relief, Pain / fever with expectorant / cough suppressant medications.
mode.32: Symptoms require a decongestant, stomach, pain / fever and expectorant with or cough suppressant relief medications.
mode.33: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, stomach an expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.34:
Okay.
You must have this flu pretty bad.

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 01:50:pm
mode_not.content2: You can compare over the counter multi-symptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Anti itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Calamine, etc

Diphenhydramine oral for night time itch.

collapsable.title: Anti inflammatory click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Hydrocortisone for inflammation

collapsable.title: Oil removal click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Content

collapsable.title: Drying agent click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Domebro astringent action.

collapsable.title: Prevention click to expand contents
collapsable.content: ivyblock, and so on

irregular.content:
Last updated by pharmacist on : 09/27/2014 at 11:04:am

Now, use this information to choose a good over the counter remedy for your poison ivy rash relief.
